entry.et: Middle English verray, verry, from Anglo-French verai, from Vulgar Latin *veracus, alteration of Latin verac-, verax truthful, from verus true; akin to Old English wǣr true, Old High German wāra trust, care, Greek ēra (accusative) favor

def.dt: :properly entitled to the name or designation :true the fierce hatred of a very woman J. M. Barrie
:actual real the very blood and bone of our grammar H. L. Smith †1972
:exact precise the very heart of the city
:exactly suitable or necessary the very thing for the purpose
:unqualified sheer the very shame of it

dt.un: used as an intensive especially to emphasize identity before my very eyes

def.dt: :mere bare the very thought terrified him
:being the same one :selfsame the very man I saw
:special particular the very essence of truth is plainness and brightness John Milton
:in actual fact :truly the very best store in town told the very same story
:to a high degree :exceedingly very hot didn't hurt very much
:a radio frequency between ultrahigh frequency and high frequency see radio frequency table

entry.et: Edward W. Very †1910 American naval officer

def.dt: :a pyrotechnic signal in a system of signaling using white or colored balls of fire projected from a special pistol
:a radio frequency between low frequency and voice frequency see radio frequency table

dt.un: used as a title for various ecclesiastical officials (as cathedral deans and canons, rectors of Roman Catholic colleges and seminaries, and superiors of some religious houses)
